siteMetadata.title: A11yTalks
siteMetadata.subtitle: Virtual meet-up featuring speakers & conversations around digital accessibility

frontmatter.title: User Trust - The Critical Metric
frontmatter.subtitle: Paul Grenier
frontmatter.description: Everything we do, as product teams, will either earn, keep, or undermine trust. From unit testing to marketing, it all affects trust. The trust between teams and team members, employees and managers, companies and customers will play a part in your success.

frontmatter.title: If It’s Interactive, It Needs a Focus Style
frontmatter.subtitle: Eric Bailey
frontmatter.description:
Focus styles don't have to be ugly! Focus styles are an integral part of any mature design system.
This talk will discuss the intersection of WCAG compliance and Inclusive Design, as well as new focus-related CSS selectors. Additionally, strategies for how to effectively implement them in your organization will be discussed.

frontmatter.title: Accessible Game Design - It’s 2 Point 1 fun!
frontmatter.subtitle: Cyndi Wiley
frontmatter.description: Long before we crushed tiny candies on our screens, dice games were among some of the first known to be played as far back as 5000 BCE. The theory of play is a well-researched area with roots in anthropology and psychology. Games have emerged throughout human history as an expression of play. Accessible game design is an area that has not been as well researched. In this presentation, you will learn how to get started checking games for accessibility using WCAG 2.1 standards, and how to get started designing your own games.

frontmatter.title: Digital Communication in the Age of COVID-19
frontmatter.subtitle: Imelda March
frontmatter.description: It seems that everyone has a message or opinion to share in the age of COVID-19. The question then is whether that message can be heard by everyone. Is your digital message accessible?

frontmatter.title: Beyond the Screen Reader - Humanizing Accessibility
frontmatter.subtitle: Alanna Burke
frontmatter.description: When we talk about accessibility, we talk a lot about the technical bits, the alphabet soup - WCAG, AAA, WAI-ARIA, Screen readers. But what we don't often talk about is what it really means to be accessible - how do we ensure we are including everyone and empowering every user in every scenario to use our sites, products, and devices? Are we including trans folks? Parents? The chronically ill? People with limited literacy? The injured? If you're wondering how these folks might be affected by accessibility and you want your website to be inclusive for everyone, this is the session for you.
